title: Majority of people HATE going against premades

The majority of people have confirmation bias, and only remember bad premades, and don't even realize they are playing with/against premades when everything goes smoothly.

And by majority, I mean more than LoL, DotA, CS:GO and other video games, I mean all people everywhere. That's just basic psychology.

For realz, do you have any idea how many Duos there were in old Solo/DuoQ?

Yeah, we get it. Confirmation bias. 

That's a factor, not some end-all argument.

Guess what? If there is a significant amount of people complaining about something statistically insignificant-- it MIGHT still be significant to address it.

That's literally an issue in every industry anywhere, you realize this too right?
People only need a relatively small amount of bad experiences with something before they get turned off of it.

Ok, THAT is a basis for some real discussion, and just not some free bashing, I'll bite. 

Sooo... If you accept, at least for the sake of the discussion, that it's not statistically significant, the good solution is NOT to remove DynQ. Then, what do you suggest? Personally, I'm inclined to think that the systems already in place with reports and all are already enough, but I'd be delighted if it could get even better.

The real problem facing DynQ, the hostility directed towards experiences with premades, is a result of the values and core gameplay already instilled by the original system. 

In the old SoloQ- there were problems too, and it was frustrating. It was a system where your individual merit was solely measured by the outcome of a team game( Which may not sound different, but-- )

That old ranked experience became canonized by a few things, and those solidified in the games' culture and community.
Things like:
-The only sure way for you to win, is for YOU to carry
-Consequently role hierarchy is established, from what role will YOU have the most impact acting ALONE

So, a 'good player' being a relative term- a good player WAS:
-Mechanically skilled enough to win their match-up by a large margin
-Able to look for opportunities to leverage that margin across the map for more advantages
-Direct others to follow their lead, or BRUTE FORCE win fights

People gave duos shit because having a known factor on your team gave you an advantage- either YOU could carry or HE/SHE could carry OR you could count on that second person to specifically help you carry rather than try to carry on their own, or vice versa. 
Either way, it displaces the burden of "The only sure way for me to win is for ME to carry"
into "The only sure way for me to win is for ME to carry, or HE/SHE to carry, or WE to carry"
Not to mention that just having someone you know you can communicate with or count on a minimum performance level takes away some of the stress altogether. 

Now, did people win games because a stranger carried the game? Of course. 
But my point is that the MENTALITY of the queue was different-- the CONFIRMATION BIAS of feeling like  "I carried that game" and remembering games where you were the carry rather than games were you were carried was very real. 
This led to the most important point- People FELT that they were very personally responsible for their victories and so they FELT that whatever they did accomplish was very much a result of their own skill. 

In DynQ, people are queuing in groups of players they can count on. Even if they aren't good, they are known quantities. They can have definite communication, they can forgo attempting to carry to help someone else to. 
The more prevalent premades become, the more the definition of a good player shifts. 

And so, people who may have thought they were a 'good player' who forged their own way in ranked through skill (Confirmation bias or not) are suddenly not feeling like good players. And no longer feeling like they matter in a meta where the only sure way to have a chance to win isn't just for you to be the carry. 

How do we fix this? How do we address a bunch of... feelings?

I don't think we fix it. It's just different and many people will never like it as much as they liked it before. 

Riot committed to a big shift in the values of the ranked scene. In a queue where teamwork is now more commonplace and viable in ranked, people who are still trying to carry alone at all costs are not seen as favorably. And when more teams are working together-- NOT working together is much more punishing than before.

I mean Riot has tried. More objectives for people to work together to get, ip incentives for premades, clubs, etc. 
For people that played thousands of games with that Solo mentality though... idk, no appeal

I agree with your analysis up to the very last paragraph:

> And so, people who may have thought they were a 'good player' who forged their own way in ranked through skill (Confirmation bias or not) are suddenly not feeling like good players. And no longer feeling like they matter in a meta where the only sure way to have a chance to win isn't just for you to be the carry. 

So first a quick remark: "thought they were a 'good player' who forged their own way in ranked through skill (Confirmation bias or not)": I talked about confirmation bias earlier, but if you reach X ranking, well, that shows you had the skills for that. I don't believe in luck on the long-term, and confirmation bias has nothing to do here. They felt good because they were good.

But then! "no longer feeling like they matter in a meta where the only sure way to have a chance to win isn't just for you to be the carry": dang, no, that doesn't follow. Because your way isn't the only way anymore, suddenly you don't matter at all? I mean, your old way is still just as valid as before, or close enough, it's just not the only one anymore. So yeah, it shifted the meaning of "good player", since there are now various way to "being good". But I really don't think it shifted it as much as people on these boards would make you believe, and if you break up the set of different skills that a Solo player needs to "be good", even a Dynamic player needs to possess most of them. I mean, good coordination with your jungler won't help you a lot if you are unable to take a single good trade in lane... And on the other hand, you also say "And when more teams are working together-- NOT working together is much more punishing than before." Yes, but you DID have to work together even before as a Solo player. You did have to "sheep-herd" people to Victory, as one Rioter put it. It's not as if Solo players really won 1v5 before, they were just trying to take the lead, but there was still team-work and cooperation.
My point is, there is a much bigger overlap than is immediately obvious between Solo and Dynamic skill-sets required to climb.

So yeah, I understand, all of this is feelings, it's hard to reason with feelings. But if people on these boards would stop the propaganda, maybe those damn feelings wouldn't be so prevalent. And I'm sorry for the harsh words, but yes, I really *feel*  (wink, wink) that we have reached propaganda levels of bad faith and misinformation regarding DynQ...

P.S.: I have to say, among all this propaganda, I enjoy the few tidbits of intelligent conversation like this one.

Very rarely do you see players complain in DotA2 about premades (they call it a stack, not a premade) but it's also kind of prevented by the fact that not only does DotA2 tell you who the highest MMR is on the enemy team (and what the average MMR is), but it's a lot easier to shut people down hard in DotA as well in comparison to League (since you lose gold for dying). This makes the problems of stacking a lot easier to deal with - the main issue with premades in League is that it is very difficult to make someone useless for the rest of the game (unlike in DotA2, as an example), which means their communication advantage remains relevant the entire game regardless of the state of the champions involved.

Premades by themselves are not a problem, but due to the rubberband-y nature of League in comparison to a moba like DotA, there's no real way to shut them down unless they're playing particular champions that you can hard counter with picks.
